Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Policy and procedures
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503
Section • (1) An agency shall have and follow written policies and
Description procedures for the independent living services provided.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency policy and procedure for independent living youth allow for
certain types of restraints in extreme circumstances.
Investigation Staff 4 was interviewed on December 5, 2024, via telephone.
She stated she is new to the Independent Living Placement (ILP)
and recently changed positions about a month ago. She is not
fully aware of the agency policy regarding incidents involving
youth who are physically aggressive and/or destroying physical
property.
Staff 5 was interviewed on December 5, 2024, via telephone.
The agency policy is to call 911 when youth are escalated and not
responding to de-escalation attempts. They can attempt to
maintain separation if they are able to safely deescalate. They are
not to touch youth at all.
Administrator was interviewed on 12/10/2024 via telephone.
She stated the staff involved, Staff 1, was terminated within the
last week after an internal investigation was completed. She
stated the program does not allow restraints. The agency does
recognize he was attempting to keep Youth A from hitting another
staff, but staff are not allowed to do a restraint.
Administrator was asked about agency policy regarding staff being
allowed to intervene in certain circumstances. When staff were
interviewed, they reported concern because Staff 1 came out of
nowhere and didn’t feel his approach was appropriate.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 12/16/2024 via telephone. He stated
the guidance given is safety first. They are to call law enforcement
if there is destruction of property.
Staff 1 was contacted but he did not respond. Attempts were
made via email on December 3, 2024, and December 10, 2024. I
later learned he was terminated by the agency as a result of this
incident.
2

Documents Reviewed:
• Holy Cross Behavior Management Policy & Procedure,
effective 11/1/2022.
Federal/State regulation(s): Licensing Rules for Foster
Family Homes & Foster Family Group Homes (R
400.9415).
Policy statement:
“It is the policy of Holy Cross Services (HCS) that all
persons served have the right to receive treatment services
free from the threat of physical management in which
person served are taken or held on the floor, chemical
restraint, seclusion, and any form of retaliatory punishment.
HCS practices a restraint-free behavior management
program throughout all program sites. However, we do
recognize that there may be extreme cases in which the
use of physical management techniques such as small child
holds without undue force, emergency restraint
EXCLUDING PRONE or escorting person served utilizing
arm support may be warranted. Such extreme cases of
physical management are conducted solely within the
context of Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI) as emergency
intervention techniques and are limited to children or
adolescents in danger of significant harm to self or others.
In most cases, emergency personnel will be contacted to
intervene, should such intervention be warranted by the
actions of a person served.”
Analysis The agency is found to be in noncompliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of agency policies and procedures the
agency states persons served have the right to receive services
free from the threat of physical management. However, the
following paragraph in the HCS Behavior Management Policy &
Procedure states “physical management techniques may be used
in extreme circumstances and are conducted solely within the
context of Crisis Prevention Institute (CPI).” Restraints are not
appropriate procedures for independent living youth.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code Staff qualifications; volunteer, contractors on central registry
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206
Section • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
Description suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
3

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A was aggressive with other youth and staff at the
placement, Youth A was restrained by Staff 1.
Investigation Staff 4 was interviewed on December 5, 2024, via telephone.
She was asked about an incident between Youth A and Youth B
and stated she witnessed some of the incident but did not see
everything. She was in the office when Youth A and Youth B were
talking but she noticed it became increasingly louder as though
they were arguing. She and Staff 2 went out into the common area
and confirmed they were arguing. Staff 1 and Staff 5 were already
present. Staff 2 went to assist with separating the youth. They
were able to keep them separate. Youth A was antagonizing
Youth B and eventually they were able to push through the staff
and get to each other but did not physically harm each other. Staff
were able to immediately separate them and then Youth A was
removed outside. She didn’t see what occurred after the youth
pushed through the staff. She did not report any concerns
regarding Staff 1.
Staff 4 noted Youth A has a history of physical aggression. In the
month she has been there he has broken several items.
Staff 5 was interviewed on December 5, 2024, via telephone.
Youth A had come in on Monday, November 18, 2024, and was
asking for his IL stipend early. They are normally distributed on
Tuesdays. She indicated the checks are only distributed early
when there are extenuating circumstances, and he would not be
able to receive his early. Upon being told no, Youth A began
flipping over tables and throwing items around. He began hitting
the lockers and at that point, another youth came out and told
Youth A not to hit the lockers because his food is stored in there
and told him to chill. They had back and forth dialogue. At that
point, Staff 5 came out of the office and got in front of Youth B and
advised him to back up. She clarified that she was facing Youth B
and had her back toward Youth A. Staff 1 went behind her and
went to where Youth A was standing. Staff 2 came and was
behind Staff 5. She was pushing Youth B forward to get him out of
the area and she felt a hand hitting her on the left side of her
chest. She turned around and it was Staff 1, Youth A and Staff 2
behind her. She didn’t notice how close they had gotten because
the last she saw Youth A was across the dining room. She
secured Youth B safely in her office. This is what she had
witnessed. She later viewed the camera footage and saw Staff 1,
Youth A and Staff 2. She noted Staff 1 and Youth A were on the
floor.
4

Staff 5 noted Youth A has a history of “crashing out” when he
doesn’t get his way, or he’s told no. He has been known to be
physically destructive. Staff 5 did not report any concerns
regarding Staff 1.
Staff 3 was interviewed on December 6, 2024, via telephone.
She stated she was present at the IL home when the incident
between Youth A and Youth B occurred. She was sitting in her
office with Staff 2 and Staff 4. They overheard a discussion that
had becoming increasingly loud and became concerned, so they
walked out to see what was happening. There was an altercation
between Youth A and Youth B. She stated they were yelling back
and forth. She witnessed Staff 1 attempt to keep Youth A away by
trying to step in front of them to create separation from Youth B.
Staff 2 stepped in between the doorway so that Youth A didn’t
harm him. Youth A is known to become escalated and physically
aggressive and destroy property. She stated he escalates when
he doesn’t get his own way. She heard a loud crash. Youth A had
flipped a table in the back room and several items fell on the
ground. She didn’t witness Staff 5 being struck by Youth A. She
denied witnessing Staff 1 restrain or physically manage Youth A.
Administrator was interviewed on 12/10/2024 via telephone.
She stated the staff involved, Staff 1, was terminated within the
last week after an internal investigation was completed. She
stated the program does not allow restraints. They recognize he
was attempting to keep Youth A from hitting another staff, but he
is not allowed to do a restraint. She reported Staff 5 told her Staff
1 did not respond appropriately and she was taken aback by the
approach Staff 1 took. However, details surrounding this wasn’t
provided. Other staff did not report seeing anything inappropriate
at the time of the incident.
Staff 2 was interviewed on 12/16/2024 via telephone. He stated
he heard yelling and came out into the hallway. Youth A and
Youth B were verbally going back and forth, and Staff 5 was in
between them. Youth A was attempting to get closer to Youth B
and ended up punching Staff 5 in her breast area. He got in
between her and the two youth. He tried to verbally deescalate
Youth A by advising him to calm down and informed him his IL
stipend check will be available for him the following day. Youth B
was initially trying to calm him down as well.
Staff 2 stated he was attempting to usher back Youth A. He does
not feel Youth A’s intent was to attack Staff 5, but he was trying to
5

get through Staff 5 to get to Youth B. He stated Staff 1 came out
of nowhere. Staff 2 believed Staff 1 came to help. Youth A was
walking back and then he charged again. He didn’t see Staff 1’s
hand placement, but he was attempting to assist Youth A with
moving back. He saw Youth A flip Staff 1 and slam him down.
Youth A put his hands on Staff 2 who advised him to remove his
hands which he did. Youth A proceeded to flip over tables and
eventually law enforcement arrived. Staff 1 did grab Youth A but
he wasn’t trying to slam him or get him to the ground. He was
attempting to separate the youth. Youth A did not end up on the
floor. Staff 2 denied witnessing Staff 1 restrain or physically
manage Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed on 12/20/24 via telephone. He stated
he requested his IL stipend check one day because he had
broken his phone. He indicated the agency had done that for other
youth in the past. He was told staff had a meeting in the morning,
so he waited. He was told the answer was no and he became
upset. Youth B approached him and began talking to him and he
became upset and the two of them were going to start physically
fighting. At that time, Staff 1 and Staff 2 got in between them. He
stated the staff pulled him back in an attempt to separate him from
Youth B. He stated this happened fast and was over quickly so he
didn’t remember many details. Youth A did not report he was
restrained by Staff 1 or physically managed by any staff.
Staff 1 was contacted but he did not respond. Attempts were
made via email on December 3, 2024, and December 10, 2024. I
later learned he was terminated by the agency as a result of this
incident.
Youth B was not able to be interviewed. He does not have a
telephone, so an interview was scheduled through the agency on
three occasions but were unsuccessful.
Video Reviewed:
Video footage of 11/18/2024 in the dining room area was reviewed
on 12/9/2024. Youth A was throwing small furniture items and
then attempted to knock over a set of lockers where youth keep
their dry food items. Youth B entered the room, and they appeared
to be verbally interacting in a calm manner. Within 1-2 minutes of
Youth A and Youth B interacting, Staff 5 entered and tried to
encourage Youth B to step back into another room. At this point
Staff 5 had her back to Youth A. Staff 1 also entered the room and
attempted to keep Youth A from advancing toward Youth B. Youth
B and Staff 5 are no longer visible in range of the camera and
6

Youth A is seen advancing toward them in an aggressive manner.
There is a short period of time where the interaction is completely
out of view of the camera. Staff 1 and Staff 2 are viewed to be
trying to bring Youth A back in the dining room away from Youth
B. Youth A threw Staff 1 to the floor. Within 1 minute, Youth A
walked away while Staff 1 walked in the direction of Staff 5 while
Staff 2 remains in the area of Youth A.
Documents reviewed:
• There are 10 review discussion forms in Staff 1’s file: 7
related to overdue and/or incomplete work, 1 related to
concerning statements of self-harm and 1 related to raising
voice to supervisor.
• December 4, 2024, termination letter addressed to Staff 1.
States Staff 1 was placed on administrative suspension on
November 18, 2024, pending the outcome of an internal
investigation related to an incident involving the use of
improper restraint of a youth.
Analysis The agency is found to be in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of video footage of the incident in question it
is determined Staff 1 was not overly aggressive with Youth A at
the independent living home. Staff denied witnessing Staff 1
restrain or physically manage Youth A and Youth A did not report
this occurring. Youth A was attempting to destroy property and
was displaying physically aggressive behavior towards another
youth in the home and staff, including Staff 1, appeared to
appropriately attempt to separate the youth before one or both of
them were harmed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
